climbs.name: Through the Looking Glass
climbs.fa: Ben Craft, Tom Murphy, Jeff Clapp 12/04

content.description:
While this route looks like an easy hand crack from the ground, it is less straightforward.  Climb through odd fingers and small hands to where the left side of the crack becomes a small headwall.  The crack widens considerably for the crux off hands move.

Overall a fun outing, but not the worth the 3 of 5 stars recommended by over enthusiastic FA'ists in Joshua Tree West.
content.protection: Standard Josh Rack.  A optional large piece could be used at the crux.
content.location:
The Looking Glass is split by an obvious hand crack on the left side of the face containing Fracture Dynamics.

Easy descent to the climber's right.

climbs.name: Pain is an Emotion
climbs.fa: Tom Murphy, Ben Craft, Jeff Clapp 12/04

content.description: This is a left leaning finger crack which goes through a couple of tiers. Crux is is the first section.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Descent to the left.
content.location: Pain is an Emotion is located on the central broken section of The Looking Glass.  Basically between the main northeast face containing Fracture Dynamics and the far left where the Birthday Crew Arere is.

climbs.name: Fracture Dynamics
climbs.fa: Tom Murphy, A. Blair, Randy Vogel 11/2007

content.description:
Fracture Dynamics climbs the center of the face, following a thin crack for most of its length.  Begin by climbing a loose crack to a ledge and clip the first bolt.  Work up and right to a second, smaller ledge, where a possible piece can be placed.  From this ledge follow the thin crack to the top.

Consistent 5.10 climbing rather than a particular crux characterizes the route.
content.protection: 6 Bolts, a few finger sized pieces,and hand size for the anchor.
content.location: The route starts just right of Through the Looking Glass on a short left leaning crack.

climbs.name: Double Stem
climbs.fa: Tom Murphy, Ben Craft, Randy Vogel 1/05

content.description: Double Stem is located to the left of the main formation behind a large boulder. Stem between the boulder and the wall to start, transitioning to the main wall at the obvious point. Powerful movement between fingerlocks is the meat of this shorty.
content.protection: #1 Camalot and smaller. Tricky pro at the bottom, strenuous to place for the rest of the way. Hand size for anchor.
content.location:
Double Stem is located on the southwest face of The Looking Glass.  It could almost be considered part of Key's Point.  From the gully between The Looking Glass and Key's Point head left (west) for 30 yards to a large boulder.  The route begins in the corridor formed by the boulder and the face.

From the northeast face, head up and left to Key's Point, and follow the above.

content.description: This short crack passes a tree about 1/2 up.  It has a few surprising moves for how easy it looks.  Not worth the walk, but maybe worth a whirl if you are up there.
content.location: On the true west end of The Looking Glass, just right of the Birthday Crew Arete.

content.description: Tricky climbing up and through a hollow flake features.  Getting good pro, especially low, is the challenge of the route.  Granted the interest factor remains high pulling through the flakes higher.
content.protection: Standard rack, esp. small cams.  Hand size plus for the anchor.  Descend right.
content.location: Bone on Bone is located on the high far right side of the south face,  About 150 yards up and right of Fracture Dynamics, just left of the Birthday Crew Arete.

content.description:
While short, the Birthday Crew Arete is high quality.  Slightly grainy at the start, it cleans up fast.  The route gradually gets harder until the crux arete moves just below the top.

What would be a well worn classic close to the road is doomed to obscurity.  If not for its length it would be 3 of 5 stars.
content.protection: 3 bolts, small nuts/cams, hand size plus for anchor.   Easy descent right.
content.location: The arete is located on the high far west side of the Looking Glass.  If approaching via the Outward Bound Slab approach, this would be the part of The Looking Glass first reached.
